questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of antidepressants?
questions.solution:
Antidepressants increase levels of neurotransmitters at the synapse by preventing their reuptake. Due to a prolonged increase in the levels of neurotransmitters, there is a change in neurotransmitter receptor sensitivity which is thought to be the major mechanism responsible for the treatment of depression.

Chronic treatment with a number of antidepressants desensitizes presynaptic autoreceptors and heteroreceptors, producing long-lasting changes in monoaminergic neurotransmission. Postreceptor effects of antidepressant treatment, including modulation of GPCR signaling and activation of protein kinases and ion channels, are involved in the mediation of the long-term effects of antidepressant drugs.

questions.text: Moclobemide belongs to which class of drugs?
questions.solution:
Moclobemide is a reversible and selective inhibitor of the MAO-A enzyme.

Monoamine hypothesis states that in depression, there is a decrease in monoamines like serotonin (5HT) and norepinephrine. These monoamines are metabolized by the enzyme monoamine oxidase (MAO). MAO inhibitors, therefore, increase these monoamines by inhibiting the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective MAO-B inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor.

Nonselective MAO inhibitors

  Selective MAO inhibitors
  • Phenelzine
  • Isocarboxazid
  • Tranylcypromine
  • MAO-A inhibitors - Moclobemide
  • MAO-B inhibitors - Selegiline, Rasagiline

questions.text: In which of the following patients is transdermal selegiline approved for use?
questions.solution:
Selegiline transdermal patch is approved for depression. The transdermal patch provides the high concentration required for antidepressant action. At higher doses, MAO-A is also inhibited and is highly effective in depression. 

Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor at low doses. It is used in Parkinson's disease at low doses, administered orally.

questions.text: A college student on MAO inhibitor therapy for depression consumed two bottles of beer during a party. The next day he started experiencing severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He was taken to the casualty by his friends where his BP was recorded to be 180/110mmHg. Which of the following compounds would be responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a hypertensive crisis in a patient on MAO inhibitor therapy is suggestive of cheese reaction, which is seen after consumption of foods rich in tyramine (beer).

Tyramine is an indirect sympathomimetic. It induces the release of catecholamines from the neurons. Tyramine can be produced in high concentrations in protein-rich foods by decarboxylation of tyrosine during fermentation.

Normally tyramine is inactivated when taken orally because it is readily metabolized by MAO in the liver. In patients who are on MAO inhibitor therapy, the tyramine taken in the diet is not inactivated and results in its increased sympathomimetic effect resulting in elevated blood pressure, termed as hypertensive crisis or cheese reaction. Drug of choice for cheese reaction is IV phentolamine.

When MAO inhibitors are taken along with SSRI or TCA, it results in serotonin syndrome due to the overstimulation of 5HT receptors. The clinical features are a triad of:

  1. Cognitive effect - delirium, coma
  2. Autonomic effects- hypertension, tachycardia
  3. Somatic effects- myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremors

questions.text: A patient presents to the medicine OPD with hypertension. He is already on imipramine for depression. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs will not be effective in him?
questions.solution:
Clonidine will not be effective in this patient.

Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant would abolish the antihypertensive effect of clonidine, by inhibiting its transport into the adrenergic neurons.

Side effects of tricyclic antidepressants:

Receptor blocked Side effects
Muscarinic receptor Anticholinergic - Dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, urinary retention
Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor Drowsiness, postural hypotension, sexual dysfunction
H1 receptor Weight gain, drowsiness

questions.text: Which tricyclic antidepressant has an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action?
questions.solution:
The tricyclic antidepressant having an additional dopaminergic receptor antagonist action is amoxapine.

Tricyclic antidepressants block the transporter of norepinephrine (NET) and serotonin (SERT) thereby preventing their uptake. Some of the TCA additionally block other receptors like alpha 1, H1, and M1.

  • TCA blocking NET selectively - desipramine, nortriptyline, amoxapine.
  • TCA blocking both NET and SERT equally - imipramine, amitriptyline.

Clomipramine, doxepin, and imipramine are tertiary amines and do not possess any dopaminergic antagonist effect.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants can be used for the treatment of a 6-year-old child diagnosed with nocturnal enuresis?
questions.solution:
Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that can be used for the treatment of nocturnal enuresis.

In children above 5 years, imipramine 25 mg at bedtime is effective for nocturnal enuresis.

Intranasal desmopressin is also effective in the treatment of nocturnal enuresis.

Option B: Amitriptyline is used in postherpetic neuralgia. It is also used in neuropathic pain.

Option C: Desipramine is used in the treatment of cocaine dependence.

Option D: Clomipramine is the best TCA for OCD.

questions.text:
Which of the following side effects of tricyclic antidepressants are correctly matched to the receptor involved in their pathogenesis?
  1. H1 receptor - sedation
  2. Muscarinic receptor - sialorrhea
  3. 5HT receptor- weight loss
  4. Alpha1 receptor - postural hypotension
  5. Muscarinic receptor - constipation
questions.solution:
The blockade of H1, alpha1, and muscarinic receptors causes sedation, postural hypotension, and constipation respectively.

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are drugs that act by inhibiting the reuptake of noradrenaline and serotonin from the synaptic clefts.

The side effects of TCAs are due to blockade of other receptors:

  • Muscarinic (M) receptors: constipation, dry mouth (not sialorrhea), arrhythmia
  • Histamine (H1) receptors: sedation
  • 5HT receptors: weight gain due to increased appetite
  • Alpha1 receptors: postural hypotension

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman having depression took multiple tablets of amitriptyline in an attempt to commit suicide. Which of the following statements regarding the management is incorrect?

choices.text: Sodium bicarbonate should be administered to treat acidosis
Atropine sulphate should be administered as an antidote
Diazepam should be injected to control seizures

questions.solution:
Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors. Atropine being an antimuscarinic drug should not be administered.

Tricyclic antidepressant overdose presents with anticholinergic effects. Hypotension occurs because of alpha1 receptor blockade.

TCAs act on Na+ channels and cause slowed conduction and depressed cardiac contractility resulting in serious arrhythmias. Seizures and agitation may occur followed by depression.

Management of TCA overdose:

  • Initial resuscitation by securing airway, breathing, and circulation.
  • Hypotension - IV fluids and norepinephrine infusion.
  • Cardiac-depressant effects - bolus dose of sodium bicarbonate helps overcome Na+ blockade by increasing extracellular Na+. It also addresses metabolic acidosis which is often present.
  • Arrhythmias - lignocaine for ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Seizures - benzodiazepines like diazepam/lorazepam.

Physostigmine can reverse anticholinergic effects but can aggravate cardiac depression and cause seizures. Therefore physostigmine is not recommended.

questions.text: A psychiatrist plans to prescribe an SSRI to a patient diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder. Which of the following was not likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is not an SSRI but a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It blocks the uptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. 

The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are:

  • Fluoxetine
  • Fluvoxamine
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Sertraline
  • Dapoxetine
  • Paroxetine

questions.text: In a middle-aged man with a history of closed-angle glaucoma, which of the following SNRIs should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine should be avoided as it is contraindicated in patients with closed-angle glaucoma. SNRIs like duloxetine and milnacipran have anticholinergic side effects like mydriasis which can precipitate closed-angle glaucoma attacks.

Duloxetine is the longest-acting SNRI with no withdrawal symptoms. In addition to the treatment of depression and anxiety, it is also used in fibromyalgia, peripheral neuropathy, and stress incontinence.

Option A: Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI with the maximum risk of withdrawal symptoms. It is approved for use in PTSD, panic disorder, and depression associated with hypotension. It is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Option C: Desvenlafaxine is a longer-acting SNRI and hence has lesser risk of withdrawal symptoms.

Option D: Fluoxetine is an SSRI, not an SNRI. It is avoided as it can cause mydriasis and narrow the angle.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man on antidepressant therapy with TCAs for the past five years is being switched to SSRIs. Which of the following would not be an advantage of this change?
questions.solution:
SSRIs have a higher incidence of sexual dysfunction when compared to TCAs. 

SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can result in loss of libido, delayed ejaculation, and interference with orgasm.

Option A: The potential of SSRIs to lower the seizure threshold is less than that of TCAs.

Options B and D: SSRIs have a selective action on serotonin reuptake with no effect on cholinergic or histaminergic receptors.

questions.text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are not the drug of choice in which of the following patients?

choices.text: A college student with an acute panic attack
An adolescent girl with social phobia
A young lady with post traumatic stress disorder
A middle-aged-man with generalized anxiety disorder

questions.solution:
In acute panic attacks, benzodiazepines or propranolol are the preferred anxiolytics. SSRIs are not the drug of choice as they have a long latent period before beneficial effects are seen.

SSRIs are considered as the drug of choice for:

  • Social anxiety disorder
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder
  • Generalized anxiety disorder
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with depression has improved symptomatically after initiating SSRIs. On discontinuing the drug, he became irritable and complained of insomnia, nausea, and flu-like symptoms. Which of the following drugs has the least risk of causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of drug discontinuation or withdrawal symptoms which are seen after sudden discontinuation of SSRIs. Fluoxetine has the least risk of causing drug-discontinuation symptoms.

Drug discontinuation symptoms of SSRIs are:

  • Nausea
  • Paresthesia
  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Irritability
  • Fatigue.

Withdrawal is least with fluoxetine as its metabolite norfluoxetine has the longest half-life. Thus the plasma level of norfluoxetine is maintained for a long time even after stopping the drug, minimizing withdrawal symptoms. Withdrawal is seen maximum with paroxetine.

questions.text: A young man with obsessive-compulsive disorder is taking SSRIs. Which of the following adverse effects would you not expect in him?
questions.solution:
Weight loss is not an adverse effect of SSRIs.

Side effects of SSRIs:

  • Nausea and diarrhea (early)
  • Loss of libido
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Headache
  • Sleep disturbances - insomnia or hypersomnia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a serotonin receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Trazodone is a serotonin receptor antagonist.

Trazodone blocks postsynaptic 5HT2A receptors and is considered an atypical antidepressant. It has weak serotonin reuptake inhibitory effect.

Nefazodone is another serotonin receptor antagonist.

Option A: Milnacipran is a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

Options C and D: Citalopram and fluoxetine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs inhibit dopamine and noradrenaline reuptake?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of noradrenaline and dopamine.

Indications of bupropion are:

  • Prevention of a seasonal depressive disorder
  • Smoking cessation
  • ADHD
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Option A :  Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that selectively blocks dopamine (D4) receptors in the brain. 

Option C : Zolpidem - It is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic. It acts as a selective agonist in benzodiazepine receptor.

Option D : Mirtazapine - block histamine (H1) receptors.

questions.text: A young woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder is refractory to first-line antidepressant therapy. The psychiatrist now decides to prescribe a recently approved NMDA antagonist. Which of the following was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Esketamine is an NMDA antagonist recently approved for the treatment of treatment-resistant depression.

Esketamine is a non-selective, non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, an ionotropic glutamate receptor. Though the exact mechanism by which it acts as an antidepressant is unknown, a single dose of intranasal Esketamine has shown to have short-term antidepressant efficacy suggesting a possible use in suicidality.

Option A: Brexanolone has GABAA modulatory action. It is given via intravenous route for post-partum depression.

Option C: Lurasidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist at dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5-HT2A) receptors. It is approved for use in depressive episodes in bipolar disorder.

Option D: Lemborexant is an orexin receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adult patients with insomnia.

Functional imaging of individuals with major depression has pinpointed excessive metabolic activity in Brodmann area 25, the subgenual prefrontal cortex, a brain region that connects to the amygdala and is thought to play a critical role in the processing of emotion-related information. This increased metabolic activity reverses with successful antidepressant treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married man complains of low energy and lack of motivation. He mentions that he feels useless and has no hope for the future. He is willing to take medication but is apprehensive about its side effects on his sexual life. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of depression. Mirtazapine can be prescribed to this patient as sexual dysfunction is not a side effect associated with its use.

Mirtazapine and mianserin block histamine (H1) receptors, and also have high antagonistic activity against 5HT2A, 5HT2C, and 5HT3 receptors. 

Due to its sedative effect, mirtazapine is also used in depression with insomnia.

Option A: Fluoxetine is an SSRI that can cause side effects like GI disturbances, risk of suicidal behavior, sexual dysfunction, and weight gain. Vilazodone is an SSRI that is not associated with sexual dysfunction or weight gain.

Option B: SNRIs like venlafaxine have side effects that include nausea, dizziness, sexual dysfunction, and risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior.

Option D: TCAs like imipramine have side effects like orthostatic hypotension, weight gain, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction, seizures, and irregular heartbeats.

questions.text: Which group does the antianxiety drug buspirone belong to?
questions.solution:
The antianxiety drug buspirone is a partial agonist of 5-HT1A receptors. The most important locations of the 5-HT1A receptor are raphe nuclei of brainstem and hippocampus. 

It mimics the antianxiety properties of benzodiazepines but does not interact with GABAA receptors or display the sedative and anticonvulsant properties of benzodiazepines. Buspirone is primarily used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.

5-HT1A partial agonists are:

  • Buspirone
  • Gepirone
  • Ipsapirone

questions.text: A psychiatry resident should not prescribe a tricyclic antidepressant to a patient having which of the following co-morbidities?
questions.solution:
Tricyclic antidepressants produce anticholinergic effects of pupillary dilatation and are thus, contraindicated in narrow-angle glaucoma.

Side effects of tricyclic antidepressants:

Receptor blocked Side effect
Muscarinic receptor Anticholinergic- dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, urinary retention
Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor Drowsiness, postural hypotension, sexual dysfunction
H1 receptor Weight gain, drowsiness

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was admitted to the emergency ward with priapism lasting for about 7 hours. A detailed history revealed the initiation of a drug for a mood disorder by a psychiatrist 3 weeks ago. Which of the following drugs is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution: Trazadone causes priapism. Intracavernous injection of phenylephrine can be used to treat priapism.

questions.text: A man feels frustrated because of his wife's decreased sexual desire. She was recently diagnosed with depression and started on a drug for the same. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is associated with the side effect of sexual dysfunction. 

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalized anxiety disorders, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder.

Other adverse effects include dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, risk of suicidal behavior, and weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhoea is not an adverse effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) mainly used to treat major depressive disorder or generalized anxiety disorder.

Nausea is the commonest side effect of SSRIs as they target the 5HT3 receptor.

Vivid dreams may occur because the drug suppresses REM sleep (the stage of dream), hence when patients eventually fall into REM sleep it may be more intense. 

Anorgasmia is the persistent inability to achieve orgasm despite responding to sexual stimulation. A proposed mechanism of escitalopram causing sexual dysfunction involves stimulation of the 5HT2C receptors.

questions.text: In children and adolescents treated with an SSRI, there appears to be an increased risk of particular ideations. Clinicians are therefore advised to remain vigilant of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used carefully in the young for the management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. In children and adolescents, there appears to be a slightly increased risk of suicidal ideations and attempts, but not of completed suicide.

Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRIs and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide).
